In this work, γ-Al2O3 supported Pt catalysts (Pt/γ-Al2O3) were prepared by adsorption method. The characteristics of the Pt catalysts were evaluated using X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption, CO chemisorption analysis and transmission electron microscopy. The influence of temperature, partial pressure of hydrogen, concentration of catalyst, and agitation speed on the formation of trans isomers during hydrogenation of sunflower oil was investigated. The results indicated that the prepared Pt catalysts exhibit excellent activity and selectivity and produce solid fat that meet the international standards, owing to the considerable decrease in the percentage of trans isomers. Low concentration of platinum (0.2%) and the possibility to reuse it opens up new perspectives for its industrial application in the process of partial hydrogenation of vegetable oils. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogenation Sunflower oil Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Activity trans isomers Abbreviations BET Brunauer–Emmett–Teller BJH Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda GC Gas chromatography HVACP High-voltage Atmospheric Cold Plasma TEM Transmission electron microscopy XRD X-ray diffraction IV Iodine value 1 Introduction Catalytic hydrogenation of vegetable oils is widely used in different countries for producing margarines, shortenings, spreads, cooking oils, and confectionary fats. The challenges encountered during the hydrogenation of vegetable oils are attributed to the variability in the composition of raw materials and stringent quality constraints of the final products [1]. The migration of double bond along the carbon chain and the alteration of its spatial configuration are associated with the intrinsic features of the mechanism of hydrogenation of linoleic acid, which is the main structural component of most natural vegetable oils used for hydrogenation (soybean oil, sunflower oil, cottonseed oil, and canola oil). As a result of these processes, up to 60% of monounsaturated acids in hydrogenated products can appear as trans isomers [2,3]. However, the presence of trans isomers in food is undesirable in accordance with the requirements of modern nutrition science. Modern studies have shown that fatty acid trans isomers cannot be digested by the human body in a natural physiological manner. These isomers accumulate inside the body, thereby reducing immunity, violating enzyme and cellular membrane activities, and contributing to an increase in the cholesterol levels in the blood. Their activities increase the risk of oncologic and cardiovascular diseases as well as diabetes [4–7]. In 2003, Food and Agriculture Organization and World Health Organization recommended reducing the level of fatty acid trans isomers to 1% of the total energy consumption [8]. Denmark was the first country to legally fix the maximum content of trans isomers in fats and oils to 2% [9]. Previously, health authorities of the European Union introduced rules pertaining to the content of trans isomers in food products containing oils and fats. For example, in USA, Canada, and countries of the EU, trans isomers are allowed in spreads and margarines at a maximum level of 2% [10–12]. Currently, Ni-based catalysts are the primary hydrogenation catalysts used in the oil and fat industry. Hydrogenation is performed at a temperature of 130°C–200°С and hydrogen pressure of 0.5–5 MPa. The products contain toxic salts of Ni, which have carcinogenic effects [13,14]. The products obtained using Ni catalysts contain considerable amounts of fatty acid trans isomers. Therefore, development of catalysts and process conditions for hydrogenation, which can reduce the content of trans isomers in the hydrogenated products, are crucial. To reduce the quantity of fatty acid trans isomers generated during hydrogenation, different catalysts, such as Rh, Ru, Pt, and Ir [15–19], were employed along with the use of dense phase fluids [20], membrane reactors [21], catalytic transfer hydrogenation [22], high-voltage atmospheric cold plasma hydrogenation [23], and electrochemical hydrogenation [24]. Veldsink et al. [25] reported that the efficacy of noble metals as catalysts for hydrogenation are arranged in the following order, Pd > Rh > Pt > Ir > Ru, based on the hydrogenation of multiple C=C bonds of fatty acids. Alternatively, they are arranged as follows: Pt <Rh < Ir <Ni < Pd, according to the generation of trans isomers in partially hydrogenated products. This work aims to study the influence of process conditions (temperature, hydrogen pressure, catalyst content, and agitation speed) on the generation of trans isomers during the hydrogenation of sunflower oil using low-percentage Pt catalysts (0.2%–1.0%) supported on γ-Al2O3. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and materials The following reagents and materials were used in this study: hexahydrate chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6.6H2O, ≥37.5% Pt, Sigma-Aldrich, USA), polyvinyl alcohol (М м: 13 000–23 000, hydrolyzed 87%, Sigma-Aldrich, USA), sodium borohydride (purity ≥99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich, USA), hydrogen (purity ≥99.99%, JSC “Kaztechgaz,” Kazakhstan), helium (purity ≥99.99%, JSC “Kaztechgaz,” Kazakhstan), standard fatty acid methyl ether (Supelco, Sigma-Aldrich, USA), and sunflower oil (Sloboda, JSC «EFKO-, Kazakhstan»). 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst To prepare colloidal particles of Pt, a solution of hexahydrate chloroplatinic acid was prepared, into which 50 mL of distilled water and a specific quantity of 1.0% polyvinyl alcohol solution were added. The resulting solution was agitated for 30 min at room temperature. Thereafter, an estimated quantity of aqueous solution of 0.1 М sodium borate was added to restore the Pt. Subsequently, the prepared Pt sol was supported onto γ-Al2O3 via adsorption, during agitation for 1 h at room temperature. Next, the catalyst was washed using distilled water, followed by filtering and drying at 110оС. Finally, catalysts with the Pt content of 0.2%, 0.5%, and 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 were obtained. 2.3 Characterization of the catalyst The catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) by employing X-ray D8 Advance A25 diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) with a monochromatic Cu Kα radiation at a wavelength of λ = 1.5417 Å. The channel voltage and electric current were 40 kV and 35 mА, respectively. The XRD patterns were recorded within a 2θ range of 10о–80о, with scan step of 0.021о sec−1. Textural properties (specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution) of the catalysts were evaluated using nitrogen physisorption at 77 K by employing ASAP 2020 instrument (Micrometrics, USA). The samples were preliminarily degasified in vacuum (residual pressure of 0.1 mmHg) at 300°C for 3 h. The specific surface area was determined using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis. The differential pore size distribution was calculated using the Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda (BJH) method. CO chemisorption experiments were carried out using the AutoChem II 2920 «Micromeritics» instrument. Adsorption isotherms for CO adsorbed on the catalysts were obtained at 308 K. The dispersion of Pt was calculated according to the CO uptake with the assumptions of CO:Pt stoichiometry of 1:1. The catalyst samples were also investigated using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with the JEM-2010 electron microscope (JEOL, Japan), with a grid resolution and acceleration voltage of 0.14 nm and 200 kV, respectively. To determine the mean diameter and size distribution of the Pt particles, histograms of the statistical results for size estimation of more than 500 particles under different TEM exposures were established. 2.4 Catalytic hydrogenation of sunflower oil Catalytic hydrogenation of sunflower oil was performed in Parr 4848 batch reactor (Parr Instrument, USA) with a volumetric capacity of 100 mL. First, 0.06 g of powdered catalysts, with particle size of 0.04–0.06 μm, and 60 mL of refined and deodorized sunflower oil were loaded in the reactor. After triple nitrogen purging of the reactor, the reaction mixture was heated and as it attained the required temperature level, the nitrogen in the reactor was replaced with hydrogen. Thereafter, agitation was performed and hydrogenation began. The hydrogenation process was stopped after the absorption of an estimated volume of hydrogen was achieved, which corresponded to an iodine value (IV) = 79–82 of the final product. After the completion of the hydrogenation, the catalyst was separated from the prepared samples by centrifugal separation. The reaction rate was calculated as the hydrogen uptake per unit time. The reaction was conducted under the following conditions: temperature of 70°C–130°С, hydrogen pressure of 0.25–1.0 MPa, and agitation intensity of 400–1000 rpm. Hydrogenation of sunflower oil can proceed in the following sequence, with the stages shown in the diagram [26]: C 18 : 2 → K 1 C 18 : 1 → K 2 C 18 : 0 . The activation energy (Eа ) was determined using the Arrhenius equation. The kinetic rate constant of hydrogenation was calculated using the first-order equation [27]: (1) K = 1 τ ln C ∘ C , where, τ is the duration of hydrogenation, C о is iodine value of the initial sunflower oil, and C is iodine value of the hydrogenated oil. 2.5 Analysis of the fatty acid composition The fatty acid composition of the initial sunflower oil and hydrogenated products (hydrogenated fats) was ascertained using gas chromatography (GC), as per ISO 12966-4:2015 [28]. Prior to the analysis, triglycerides of the fatty acids were transformed into their methyl ethers, as per ISO 12966-2:2017 [29]. The generated methyl ethers of the fatty acids were analyzed on the “Chromos GX-1000” gas chromatograph (“Chromos,” Russia) with a flame-ionization detector using capillary column СP-Sil 88 with dimensions of 100 m × 0.25 mm × 0.20 μm (Agilent Technologies). The analysis was performed under the following temperature conditions: 100°С—dwell time of 4 min—heating at a rate of 5°С/min up to 170°С—dwell time of 20 min. Thereafter, the temperature was increased up to 240°C at a rate of 5°С/min followed by subsequent dwell time of 18 min at the final temperature. The total duration for the chromatographic analysis was 70 min. Helium was used as the carrier gas. The volume of the injected sample was 0.5 μL. The identification of methyl ethers of the fatty acids was performed based on their retention time compared with standard Supelco mixture 19945 (FAME Mix, C4-C24). 2.6 IV The IV of the initial and hydrogenated oils was calculated from the fatty acid composition obtained by GC analysis using the following equation [30]: (2) I V = [ ( % C i s 18 : 1 + % t r a n s C 18 : 1 ) × 0.86 ] + [ ( % C i s 18 : 2 + % t r a n s C 18 : 2 ) × 1.732 ] + [ ( % C i s 18 : 3 + % t r a n s C 18 : 3 ) × 2.616 ] 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the γ-Al2O3 and Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst samples. The XRD patterns of Pt/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the same trend as that of initial γ-Al2O3. The primary diffraction peaks at 37.6°, 45.8°, and 66.8° corresponded to Al2O3 in all the samples. Moreover, the diffraction peaks corresponding to Pt nanoparticles were not observed, possibly because of the low content of Pt (0.2%–1.0%) in Pt/γ-Al2O3. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with metal content of 0.2%, 0.5%, and 1.0% and the differential curves of pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 2 a and b, respectively. Fig. 2a indicates that all the Pt catalysts samples belong to the type IV isotherms with H1-type hysteresis loops, which according to the IUPAC classification are characteristic of cylindrical mesopores that are open from all sides [31]. Using the BET analysis, the specific surface area of 0.2% and 0.5% Pt/γ-Al2O3 was determined to be 254.0 m2/g, whereas that of 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 was determined to be 252.0 m2/g. As can be observed from the differential curves (Fig. 2b), the mean pore diameters of all the catalyst samples were calculated as 10.5 nm, using the BJH method. Table 1 summarizes the textural characteristics and dispersion of the Pt catalyst samples. The date in the table suggest that the dispersion of platinum in these systems is in the range of 30-45%. Fig. 3 a-c present the TEM images of the catalysts and the histogram of particle size distribution of Pt. All TEM images indicate that the Pt particles exhibited a shape similar to a sphere. According to the statistical estimations, which were based on TEM data, the particle sizes of Pt in 0.2%, 0.5%, and 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 were 1–5 nm, with the primary size of 2–3 nm for all the three catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic hydrogenation of sunflower oil 3.2.1 Effect of reaction temperature The activity of 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst during the hydrogenation of sunflower oil was evaluated at varying temperatures of 90°C–150°C and hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa. The oil to catalyst weight ratio was 1:1000, and the constant agitation speed was 800 rpm. Fig. 4 a and b depict the reaction rate for hydrogenation, which depends on hydrogen uptake and hydrogenation kinetic curves of sunflower oil using the 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at different temperatures. From Fig. 4, it can be observed that at hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa, the activity of the Pt catalyst increased with an increase in the temperature. Fig. 4 shows that the reaction rate for hydrogenation of sunflower oil using the Pt catalyst was stable at 70°C, 90°C, 110°C, and 130°C. The apparent activation energy for the hydrogenation of sunflower oil was obtained from reaction rate constants at various temperatures using the Arrhenius equation, and this dependence is depicted in Fig. 5 . During hydrogenation of sunflower oil using 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the apparent activation energy was 28.9 kJ/mol. Table 2 shows the composition of fatty acids in the hydrogenated samples of sunflower oil. Based on the GC analysis, during the hydrogenation of sunflower oil using 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, as the process temperature was decreased from 130°C to 70°C, the percentage of trans isomers in the hydrogenated products decreased from 8% to 3.5% (Table 2). Increasing the reaction temperature increases the reaction rate; however, the percentage of trans isomers in the end products also increases. In fact, as the reaction rate increases, the hydrogen concentration on the catalyst surface decreases to scarcity, thereby promoting the formation of semihydrogenated intermediates and increasing the content of trans isomers in the hydrogenated products [32,33]. 3.2.2 Effect of Pt content in the catalyst The influence of Pt content in the catalyst (0.2%, 0.5%, and 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3) on the rate of hydrogenation of sunflower oil at 90°С was investigated. The reaction rate as a function of hydrogen uptake and the kinetic curves for hydrogenation of sunflower oil using the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 a and b, respectively. Table 3 shows the fatty acid composition of hydrogenated fat obtained during the hydrogenation of sunflower oil. Fig. 6a shows that at low temperature (90°C), the rate of hydrogenation increases 2–3 times with increase in the Pt content of the catalyst. During the hydrogenation of sunflower oil at 90°C using the Pt catalyst in the kinetic region, the reaction rate was proportional to the Pt content. Fig. 7 demonstrates the dependence of the initial reaction rate on the Pt content, which clearly indicates a linear correlation. This finding proves that mass transfer of hydrogen from the gaseous to the liquid phase does not limit the transformations on the catalyst surface [34]. According to GC data (Table 3), increasing the Pt content from 0.2% to 1.0% at the same temperature and pressure did not affect the selectivity for the hydrogenation of sunflower oil. The content of trans isomers in the hydrogenated fat varied over a narrow range of 3.7%–4.5%. 3.2.3 Effect of agitation speed The effect of agitation speed (400–1000 rpm) on the reaction rate for hydrogenation of sunflower oil was examined at a temperature and hydrogen pressure of 90°C and 0.5 MPa, respectively. Fig. 8 a and b show the reaction rate for hydrogenation as a function of hydrogen uptake and kinetic curves for hydrogenation of sunflower oil at different agitation speeds using the 1.0% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Table 4 presents the fatty acid composition of the hydrogenated fat obtained during the hydrogenation of sunflower oil. Fig. 8a and b show that the hydrogenation of sunflower oil using the 1.0%Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at low agitation speeds (400 and 600 rpm) decreases the reaction rate and increases the reaction time, thereby increasing the content of trans isomers (6.5%) and stearic acid (24.4%) in the end products (Table 4). This may indicate the occurrence of the reaction in the diffusion region. Decrease in the agitation speed dramatically reduces the rate of reagents’ supply and removal of the reaction products from the catalytic surface. However, becausehydrogen molecules are hundred times smaller and considerably more mobile than triglycerides, as the agitation speed decreases, the diffusion of triglycerides is restrained at the first instant. Increasing the agitation speed to 800–1000 rpm eliminates these phenomena. Furthermore, the rate and selectivity of hydrogenation increases, and the reaction transfers to the kinetic regime, which decreases the formation of trans isomers in the final products. When the agitation speed is increased to 1000 rpm, the content of trans isomers decreases to 4.4% (Table 4). This observation can be related to the fact that with an increase in the agitation speed, the rates of hydrogen transport to the catalyst surface and desorption of the reaction product from the catalyst surface also increases, thus diminishing the probability of generation of trans isomers. The obtained results correspond well with the data provided in literature [35,36]. 3.2.4 Effect of hydrogen pressure Fig. 9 a and b show the effect of hydrogen pressure (0.25–1.0 MPa) on the hydrogenation of sunflower oil using the 1.0%Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at a temperature of 90°С. The catalyst to oil ratio was 1:1000, and the agitation speed was 800 rpm. When the hydrogen pressure was increased from 0.25 to 1.0 MPa, the hydrogenation reaction rate increased by three times (Fig. 9a) and the reaction time decreased (Fig. 9b). Increasing the hydrogen pressure increases the hydrogen content and promotes the transport of additional content of hydrogen through the oil layer to the catalyst surface. Under these circumstances, hydrogen atoms totally cover all the active catalyst centers. When the hydrogen pressure was increased within an interval of 0.25–1.0 MPa (Fig. 10 ), the initial reaction rate linearly increased, thus proving the occurrence of a first-order reaction with respect to hydrogen. Table 5 shows the fatty acid compositions of the sunflower oil samples hydrogenated at different hydrogen pressures. From Table 5, it can be observed that the percentage of trans isomers decreased from 5.6% to 3.5 % at the temperature of 90°С and by increasing the hydrogen pressure from 0.25 to 1.0 MPa. Some researchers reported [37,38] that high pressure severely reduces the formation of trans isomers. Cheng et al. [39] reported that during the hydrogenation of soybean and cotton seed oils using Ni, Pd, and Pt catalysts at hydrogen pressures of 2–5 MPa, the content of trans isomers decreases (IV: 70–95 g I2/100 g) at high pressure. Konkol et al. [40] has shown that similar results are achieved during the hydrogenation of rapeseed oil at a temperature of 180°C and hydrogen pressure of 1.5–2 MPa, using a Ni catalyst in a batch reactor. During vegetable oil hydrogenation, increasing the hydrogen pressure changes the concentration ratio between the triglyceride molecules and active hydrogen on the catalyst surface. Thus, at high pressures, hydrogen molecules have time to form a bond with C=C before the triglyceride molecules turn around the C–C bond; therefore, hydrogenation occurs at a higher rate than isomerization. Consequently, a lower content of trans isomers in the hydrogenated products is observed. If the hydrogen coverage is low, then the absorbed polyunsaturated fatty acids will react partially with the metal surface via the second double bonds. It is obvious that in such situations, the adsorption binding energies of mono (С18:1) and polyunsaturated (С18:2) acids will considerably differ, which will lead to monopolization of the surface by linoleic acid. Such conditions will prevent oleic acid transformation and contribute to the increase in the percentage of trans isomers in the reaction products [41,42]. 3.2.4 Reuse of platinum catalysts The activity and selectivity of the 1.0% and 0.2% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts (110°C, 0.5 MPa, 800 rpm) were investigated during reuse in the hydrogenation of sunflower oil by filtering the catalyst from each hydrogenation product. After each cycle, the catalyst was collected using centrifugation without washing any solvents, and dried at 80°C for 3 h under vacuum. The reaction rate as a function of hydrogen uptake during hydrogenation of the successive weights of sunflower oil is illustrated in Fig. 11 . Fig. 11a and b showed that even at reuse the catalyst maintains sufficiently high activity. Under the same reaction condition, 1.0% and 0.2% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were reused for hydrogenation of sunflower oil at least four and two times, respectively. Table 6 presents the results of chromatographic analysis on the products obtained by reuse of catalysts in the sunflower oil hydrogenation process. It can be seen from Table 6 that after reuse the concentration of trans isomers in the obtained products varies narrowly between 6.1 and 6.7%. 4 Conclusions It was found that Pt particles were uniformly distributed on the surface of Al2O3, and the particle sizes were in the range of 1–5 nm, with predominant sizes of 2–3 nm. It was experimentally shown that the use of Pt catalysts during the hydrogenation of sunflower oil at low temperatures, high hydrogen pressures, low catalyst content, and high agitation speeds reduce the content of trans isomers in the final products. Low percentage (0.2-1.0%) platinum catalysts could be reused at least 2-4 times without considerable loss in high activity and selectivity for the hydrogenation of sunflower oil. Moreover, the use of low percentage of Pt catalysts will facilitate obtaining of ready-made fat and oil products (margarine and spread) with a trans isomer content of less than 2% and a saturated acid content of no more than 25%. coredata.dc:description: In this work, γ-Al2O3 supported Pt catalysts (Pt/γ-Al2O3) were prepared by adsorption method. The characteristics of the Pt catalysts were evaluated using X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption, CO chemisorption analysis and transmission electron microscopy. The influence of temperature, partial pressure of hydrogen, concentration of catalyst, and agitation speed on the formation of trans isomers during hydrogenation of sunflower oil was investigated. The results indicated that the prepared Pt catalysts exhibit excellent activity and selectivity and produce solid fat that meet the international standards, owing to the considerable decrease in the percentage of trans isomers. Low concentration of platinum (0.2%) and the possibility to reuse it opens up new perspectives for its industrial application in the process of partial hydrogenation of vegetable oils.
coredata.dc:title: Partial hydrogenation of sunflower oil on platinum catalysts: Influence of process conditions on the mass content of geometric isomers
